name: Katrina Rodabaugh
bio:
🔹Remaking fashion & home to be earth friendlier. 
🔹Author of Make Thrift Mend and Mending Matters.
🔹Mending, plant-dyes, redesign.
🔹Hudson Valley, NY.

social_posts.post_text:
December, you edgy, tender, rich, potent, heart-filled month, you. In honor of this seasonal tenderness--and the makers, stitchers, and dreamers everywhere-- I've created a new maker's kit, For the Love of Blue. With the arrival of December, my garden is firmly put to rest and I just want to sit by my wood stove and knit, stitch, write, and read all the pretty design books.
🔹
I've written before about how this season fills me with deep grief but that grief beckons for softness too. It wants the antidotes of ache like spaciousness, coziness, and the possibility of new creative adventures. It wants something to look forward to. It wants beauty, inspiration, deep joy.
🔹
This new kit is inspired by my love of blue--the deepest, richest, most majestic blues that remind me of clear midnight skies filled with stars over solstice bonfires. Those blues. It contains silk threads, pearl threads, cotton threads, a hand-dyed organic cotton bandana, needles, a sketching notebook, and more.
🔹
I hope you curl up with this kit and dream your way into a joyful New Year. Soon. There are also a few Mending Tool Kits, naturally-dyed scarves, my signed books, and letterpress prints on offer. For your crafty, earth-loving, slow fashion adventures or for your beloveds. Welcome, December.

I’ve just learned that my second book, Mending Matters, is going into its ninth printing. What?!? It’s unbelievable. That’s so far beyond my wildest dreams as an author. Thank you so, so much for supporting my work.
🔹
People often ask me, what’s the difference between these two books? Well, Mending Matters was published in 2018 and it’s focused on mending by hand-stitching repairs on woven fabrics like denim, linen, cotton and silk. Make Thrift Mend was published in 2021 and is the absolute heart and soul of my slow fashion project—it has three sections: sustainable sewing, natural dyes, and mending on woven and knit fabrics.
🔹
Thank you for buying my books, carrying them in your shops, sharing them with your community, or borrowing them from your library. It means the world to me! My first book, The Paper Playhouse, was published in 2015 and these past eight years have been absolutely life-affirming as an artist and writer. Thank you! Available anywhere books are sold online, in-person, or signed copies on my site too.

Mending. All the things in all the ways. The torn jeans, the broken hearts, the outdated expectations. Mending what moves too fast and, simultaneously, what waits too long in the shadows. Mending what’s gone missing and what’s taking up too much space. Mending again, and again, and then more mending. Circular, ongoing, ever-present.
🔹
This time of year is so full. It’s joyful and merry but it can also be tiring and tug us too far from our centers. I try to slow it down. Stretch it out. Stand back and witness. But it charges ahead anyway, dramatic, enthusiastic, eager. I find the quiet moments where I can—a cold morning walk, an extra cup of hot tea, an added moment for handwork.
🔹
What I’m trying to say is, there’s no right or wrong way to pour your heart into slower holidays and early winter. I’ll build a bonfire, I’ll bake more cookies, and I’ll do my best to keep intentions aligned and hearts fully intact. I’ll try to be gentle when I misstep. But it’s all mending, really, the patching and stitching of an everyday life. Even during the holidays. Maybe, if I’m lucky, near a sunny window when a Northern Cardinal flies by. Take a breath, pause, notice, shift, keep going.

Creativity under pressure—for many of us, these next few weeks will look very different from the rest of the year. Particularly for parents, caregivers, and self-employed folks trying to step away to make merry. We might be traveling, hosting, or planning events too. But we can still make time for our personal creative practice, even in micro sessions.
🔹
If we can just carve out 15 minutes a day, most days, it helps to reset, reconnect, and nudge creativity back towards the center. It allows us to honor our need for expression and decompression too. Just 15 minutes to write, stitch, knit, draw, sew, or even envision the next creative steps. Let’s just try it, let’s just see how it feels. No pressure, just permission to create just for you. One day at a time.

Happy Winter Solstice. What a moment to remember all the endings and beginnings in a day, a season, a year. What a metaphor for hope and moving through the darkness with incredible tenderness in trust that the light will come. The pull of the darkness and the pulse of the light. Simultaneously.
🔹
I cannot summarize this past year in a handful of sentences. I cannot list all the floods of darkness or rainbows of light. But I can take this one day, this darkest day, to officially welcome winter and her gifts. I have to work harder to see the offerings this time of year but I appreciate the wisdom that arrives—blurry, somedays, with sleet and ice keeping us all indoors but still, fortitude and patience are dear guests.
🔹
As the plants pour their energy into their roots, we can too. We go inwards, we get pensive, and we navigate through introspection. It’s a time to reflect on the year behind and set intentions for the one ahead—what we want to shed or grow. It’s a time to celebrate. Together. A marvel of packed snow, a homemade cake, maybe a bonfire at dusk. Whatever yours is, may it be tender, may it be hopeful, may it feel bright. Happy Solstice.

Happy New Year to you! And Happy Birthday to me and all the dear Capricorns everywhere. This day is always so potent as it marks the turn of the calendar year and the turn of my birth year too. The day buzzes. It rustles. It hums. And I just try to pause long enough to notice.
🔹
I don’t have resolutions but I do set intentions. I do reflect on what the past year offered and what I want to lessen or expand. I sit by the wood stove with my dear husband, on New Year’s Eve, and make my list of 10 hopes for the next year. He does the same. Then we share lists. Each year there is overlap and yet there are surprises. Thank goodness.
🔹
This moment feels very full of the everyday. It feels round, flush, saturated with parenting and work and home and midlife. Warmly so. I have big questions for 2023 that I might not answer. Dreams I might not quite reach. Yet it’s a miracle just to witness. Happy New Year to you and yours! May it be everything. Anything. May it saunter then, surprisingly, pirouette.

I recently sent these mended jeans off to an exhibition. It felt surreal in many ways, celebratory, and oddly intimate. I started my slow fashion project, Make Thrift Mend, ten years ago and these jeans are a stitched diary of my journey. My very first mend is under one knee patch, wonky and oddly-shaped and too stiff for my liking. I kept experimenting with stitches and patches for a decade.
🔹
They’ve been patched more than 25 times. They’re patched all down the legs from the pockets to mid-shins. There are multiple patches in the upper thighs—some more visible than others. The back pockets are patched. And, most recently, the belt loops too. They’re almost more patch and stitch than original denim. Almost. I’ve committed to mending them, impossibly, forever. Impractical, yes, but as a beloved art object, fairly practical too.
🔹
There’s so much I could write about these jeans, mending as a metaphor, social practice, and letting our studio habits evolve. When I started this project I wanted to take a break from fashion consumption, make art that was personal and wearable, and shift my studio from art objects (that might be exhibited, sold, or endlessly stored) to social practice, teaching, and community-building. I thought the project would be a year, not a decade, nor a lifetime.
🔹
Now I think mending is everything and most everything needs mending. Plant dyes are mending, slow design is mending, sewing with secondhand fabric is mending, activism is mending, and sharing narratives as a working mom is mending too. But these jeans—they’re the mending I’ve carried with me and now parted with for the very first time. A milestone. A shift. A new (old) offering. PS—Exhibition details coming soon.

I’m so excited to teach visible mending in London, England this spring! I’ll be teaching two workshops on Sunday, April 2 and I am absolutely thrilled. I hoped to travel to London to celebrate my last book, Make Thrift Mend, in 2021 but the pandemic interfered. What a delight to celebrate all things mending and repair this spring.
🔹
I’m teaching at the beautiful @looplondonloves on that Sunday morning and afternoon. Visiting Loop has been on my wishlist for years and I’m thrilled to teach there soon. I’m eager to connect with the craft community, talk sustainable fashion, and mend all the textiles with love and care. We’re making it a family trip with half our time in the city and half in the countryside. Class details are now on the Loop website. Did I mention I’m excited?!? 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿 🧵 ❤️

I’m offering a new online class, Creative Practice, on Sunday, February 19. In this class, I’ll share my creative process and guide you through exercises to center your creative work right now in your full, imperfect, inspired life. This is my fourth iteration of this work but my first time offering it to the public. The full title is, Creative Practice: Birthing Big Art Dreams and Pivoting from Dreaming to Doing with Deep Love and Wonder.
🔹
Creative practice is the ongoing work of making art—it’s the daily rituals, ordinary systems, and organized tasks. In this class, you’ll focus on what you most want to make in your life right now, how you want to share it with the world, and who will support you in this journey. You’ll demystify the creative process while holding space for the magical muses because it turns out, it takes structure and inspiration—on repeat.
🔹
Based on ten years of my slow fashion project, Make Thrift Mend, and twenty-five years of working in the arts, I will share my personal approach to creativity, work flow, and daily habits while raising two children, growing a small business, authoring three books, repairing an ancient farmhouse, and being a passionate yet often-distracted human. Class is half full and this is my first post! If you’re interested, hop over for details. Class is live on Feb 19 (the new moon) with a recording and pdf.

I’ve received some great questions about my new online class, Creative Practice, so I want to share some more details. This class is designed for *any level* of creative work by any creative human—whether you’re knitting a first scarf, writing a fifth book, updating a studio space, or just know you want more time for creativity in your life. It’s all applicable.
🔹
I’ll share what I’ve learned from twenty-five years in the arts and what I’ve had to articulate from the last year of sharing my process in my membership space. I’ve learned that my creative projects tend to follow the same 8-step process whether I’m sewing a dress or writing a book. It’s my own personal process and I’ll share it with you.
🔹
We’ll brainstorm, journal, make maps, and identify support in our lives to center creativity in our full days and weeks. This class is about *you and your work*. You bring the creative project and a willingness to share, I provide the structure, and together we create a community that focuses on creative practice together for an afternoon. Class will be live on Sunday, February 19, (the new moon) with a recording, and a pdf. Details over on my site. 💙🕯️🌑🌟🧵UPDATE: This class is now soldout. Stay tuned for other offerings.

I knit a vest! And I made a dress. And on one warm winter day I wore them together. This feels like a special moment because the vest is the first garment I’ve ever knit. Ever! I’ve knit several hats, scarves, shawls, and one pair of mittens—but this is the first garment that had to fit my one human body and… it fits. Hallelujah!
🔹
I just pulled the vest off my needles a few weeks ago and I’ve worn it many times since. Here it’s paired with a dress I made last winter and they feel like a happy duo. I’m rounding the first decade since launching my project, Make Thrift Mend, to focus on slow fashion but most of my clothes are still secondhand, many are plant-dyed or mended, some are new, and I’m always thrilled to add more homemade garments to my collection.
🔹
It takes time, focus, and technical skill to make clothes from start to finish. As a mom running a small business, I don’t always have those resources to spare. But when I do carve out the time it’s such fulfilling work. And it lets me add one-of-a-kind clothes to my wardrobe in the size, color, texture, pattern, and fit that I want. Feels like magic. Details: The vest is the Brechin Vest pattern by @good_night_day and the dress is the Hinterland Dress pattern by @sewliberated Oh, and I got a haircut too.

I have two children aged 11 and 7-years-old. I write about them but don’t post photos of them much. It’s a privacy thing, mostly, and wanting them to have choice in their public lives. But it goes without saying they’re two of my favorite people on the planet. I mean, like, my very favorite humans. And I absolutely love being their Mama.
🔹
But it’s still impossible to balance work and home life. I don’t think that 50/50 balance really exists. Mine is a messy, full, wonderful and passionate life often tight on time. I love my sons fiercely and they know it. I love my work deeply and they know that too. I recently posted in stories about having kids home for unplanned sicknesses before and after a long weekend. It sunk me at work. Ugh. Sometimes it just piles up.
🔹
But in this sinking I’m reminded not “this is the problem with working moms” (ouch, no) but this is the problem with not having more support for working moms, primary caregivers, and also art parents. We need flexible work schedules, community support, opportunities to work from home and more mom-friendly art spaces. That’s just a start. It’s too much to summarize but I’ll say this, if you’re sinking with kids/ work, you are not alone. Ever. There’s an army of us.
🔹
And now, both boys finally went back to school today. I’m catching up on emails. Nudging projects forward. And working on a pretty awesome to-do list because that’s what sets me straight. I’m also happy just to have picked up my house and made myself lunch. It’s both/and. I’m a full human. You’re a full human. Let’s remember that, please. And support the working mothers and parents in our lives. Happy Thursday. (Please do not repost photos of my babies, thank you.)

What’s your favorite book on creativity? Or more specifically, what’s your favorite book on creative habits and the process? As I prepare to teach a second section of my new class, Creative Practice, on March 18 I’m revisiting some of my favorites. And I’d love to add your favorites to my ever-expanding research list. Oh, please do tell me yours.
🔹
There’s no one way to have a creative life. No singular book, structure, or schedule that will let everything just slip, effortlessly, into place. It’s another myth we’ve been fed—that of the effortlessly successful artist, writer, or designer. I can’t even write that sentence without my stomach churning. Yes, it can be intuitive and expressive but every artist I know also has structures, schedules, and ways of organizing or creating containers.
🔹
While we all need something a bit different, it’s so inspiring to learn about the habits and mindsets of other creative folks. So, what’s your favorite book on the topic? Will you share it in the comments so we can all expand our lists? Double points if the books have takeaways like The Artist’s Way offers morning images, and is somehow missing from my bookshelf. Hmm. (Authors tagged in second photo.)

Swiss darning—what a delight! It’s a great way to reinforce worn areas of knitted garments and even highlight plant-dyed yarn like those used here. It’s also a fun repetitive stitch that creates simple stripes or lines by just alternating yarn. I still prefer basic darning for large holes or rips that need the repair of newly woven yarns, like the repair on the left elbow of this sweater. But why not use both? Depending on the mend.
🔹
One thing I love so much about mending is that it forces me to slow down and observe. Each repair requires me to assess the damage, fiber, color, textile and original design, and then to create a unique repair based on those assessments. It resists monotony. It requires attentiveness. And ongoing experimentation. It requires thought and allows for expression. Also, as repair work is ongoing it even allows me to repair my repairs, to pivot. Oh, the metaphors for healing and creative practice are endless!
🔹
I love that mending also resists perfectionism. I love that darning is sometimes wonky—weft or warp is uneven; new yarn tacks into existing yarn at imperfect angles; and even practiced stitches are asked to embrace levity and resist rigidity as they bend to embrace worn fiber. It’s too much to condense but pretty much… mending is everything and everything is mending! Or it can be. If we let it.

Next week we fly to England! We’re heading to London and Brighton and East and West Sussex and I am absolutely over-the-moon with excitement. I’m borrowing all the library books, combing my bookshelves, and researching all things British art and design. We’re just there for ten days but I’d love your recommendations.
🔹
I’ll be teaching two (sold out) mending classes at the beautiful @looplondonloves in London. I’m also planning on the @ceciliavicuna and Magdalena Abakanowicz exhibitions at the @tate with hopes of visiting @whitechapelgallery and @vamuseum too. And the @devolkitchens and @libertylondon showrooms are on my list. I’d love your recommendations on any bookstores, cafes, restaurants, independent shops, or favorites spots in London. Oh, please, yes!
🔹
Then we’re heading south from London with stops in East Sussex, Brighton, and West Sussex with a highly anticipated visit to @charlestontrust We have hopes for visiting castles, gardens, and village pubs. My husband, 11-year-old, and 8-year-olds are my travel companions. If you have any suggestions, I’m all ears, eyes, and eager heart. (Books and/or artists tagged in photos.)

Oh, London, I love you so! What an amazing adventure of museums and double-decker buses and theater and long walks and more museums. I was here 26 years ago and again 17 years ago and I’m not sure what kept me away this long (babies, pregnancies, moving 3,000 miles to DIY repair an old farmhouse, then a global pandemic, perhaps) but it’s so good to be back. With my dear family in tow.
🔹
It’s too much to share in one post but some favorite moments were the @ceciliavicuna and Magdalena Abakanowicz at @tate and the plant-dyed and hand-printed textiles at the @vamuseum and The Tempest at @the_globe theater and the beautiful tiles and blooms everywhere and each time we rode in the front seats upstairs on the double-decker buses. Each ride was just perfect.
🔹
And what a joy to teach mending at @looplondonloves and marvel at the beauty in every corner and spend the day with delightful students. Makes my heart swell, this work with fiber and sustainability and creativity. I can’t yet process the impact of this massive trip but I can already see the need to adventure more often, particularly in my everyday life and work back home.

And then five more days in the English countryside visiting castles and gardens and artists’ former homes and expanses of hills where white cliffs plummet to cold water. It’s too much to pack into one post but, my gosh, I must try. It’s the bright green hills I see in hindsight—verdant and vibrant tumbling aside narrow roads beyond dense hedges.
🔹
Some moments that shined brightest were the gardens at @sissinghurstcastlegardennt and the castles at @bodiamcastlent and @scotneycastle_nt Daffodils and fritillary and meeting the dye plant, Gorse. The cliffs at @southdownsnp and the stunning fabrics at @merchantandmills and meeting up with old friends for just a moment and @charlestontrust Oh, the fabrics of Charleston and so much about Vanessa Bell. And a delicious meal in Brighton and did I mention the daffodils? The hills? A full moon cast across the dense hedges?
🔹
I was last in England in 2006 and that feels oddly close and also lifetimes ago. These years have undoubtedly changed me—marriage, motherhood, repairing an old home, running a small business—but there’s an ageless wonder that returns. Timeless. I felt that so much this trip—wide-eyed, curious, inspired. I want that part to linger—the wonder, mostly, the new ways of seeing.

Appliqués as Mending: This secondhand jacket needed an update and so a massive moon appliqué was my answer. It was so much fun to create the patchwork from tiny fabric scraps and play around with design elements like line, space, shape, and value. And now I have a first quarter moon on my back—stitched during yesterday’s eclipse.
🔹
One thing that’s kept me interested in mending for the past decade is that I keep expanding the definition. Lately, everything is mending and mending is everything. I think we can all agree so much needs mending. So much. But I’m also thinking practically about mending as stitching, patching, darning, but also appliqué, patchwork, overdyeing with plants and more.
🔹
Spring brings renewal, my heart lifts in increments with each blossom and the return of each plant for food, medicine, or dyes. Now this jacket brings renewal too. Like a hug. Like hope. No, I don’t think this jacket is going to mend the world, but I do think it offers a deeper connection to my wardrobe, an opportunity for creativity, and a simple joy.
🔹
Details: secondhand, white linen jacket dyed blue with fermented indigo, appliquéd with various patchwork fabric scraps and basic muslin, hand-stitched; secondhand silk top dyed with goldenrod flowers; secondhand skirt was a gift from friend @brece_honeycutt Flowering Quince branches, which are a dye plant too.

ALL THE FLOWERS AND MENDED THINGS. May has arrived with a quickened pace and heavy rainstorms and magnificent purple lilacs. Blooming dogwoods and our old mended floors and new tiny mends on my sweaters too. We made our first rhubarb compote of the season, albeit on an electric burner in my dye studio in the back of our garage because our kitchen is a construction site in hopes of greener design. Nothing is perfect, everything is practice, and yet I just want to photograph every flower as it blooms.
🔹
There are soccer games and band concerts and band auditions and upwards of twelve tadpoles growing tiny legs in my garage as I type. Everything is a science experiment for my 8-year-old and every day he’d rather search for salamanders instead of anything else. I can’t argue. I’m planning two very exciting, very special, weekend retreats in my barn this summer and fall with two very beloved fiber artists. I’ll tell you more soon, so soon.
🔹
Mostly, I wonder where the time goes from May through December and try to capture those moments so I can remember them from January through April. I’m trying to share glimpses here and elsewhere, just in the mess of a creative life instead after the projects are done. I’m learning that slow fashion and slow interior design aren’t so different, though there’s relief in being a novice and a self-taught practitioner of both—Intention, imperfections, mending, and making meaning as we go. With purple lilacs blooming along these backroads, my word. A poet’s heart.

I’m beyond excited to share that I will host and co-teach a weekend fiber arts retreat in my barn studio this summer. And I’m so delighted to welcome Sara Buscaglia of @farmandfolk as my collaborator for a very special weekend on Aug 4-6. Sara will travel from Colorado for her first ever East Coast workshop, Making Matters: Hand-Quilting and Plant Dyes. We can’t wait to make things with you!
🔹
This workshop is an immersion in handcraft that embraces stitchwork and plant dyes; values a thoughtful, slow design process; follows creative intuition; and honors an intimate relationship to materials to make one-of-a-kind textiles. Sara and I will share our processes in plant dyeing, stitching, and hand-quilting to lead participants through a heartfelt exploration of creating objects that express a love of place, people, plants, and process. This promises to be a very special weekend for textile lovers.
🔹
The workshop includes dyeing and hand-quilting instruction; various beautiful textile materials; shared tools; individual feedback; thoughtful vegetarian lunches, snacks and tea; and a rural setting to connect with other creatives in the heart of the Hudson Valley’s beautiful landscape. Registration opens at 11am EST on Friday, May 19. Details on my site. (All photos by Sara of @farmandfolk .) I’m so excited to collaborate with you, Sara!

Hand stitching adds so much sentiment and value and resonance to a garment. My definition of mending just keeps expanding from stitching and patching and darning to plant dyes and patchwork and embroidery and applique and redesign. When we add value we add longevity. We’re less likely to castoff textiles that have added value which includes handwork, sentiment, connection, symbolism, beauty, and much more.
🔹
It’s all mending—patching the holes in our jeans, healing the fissures in our relationships, and fixing the floorboards in our old homes. I’m happiest when I can slow it all down to handwork—the colors, the lines, the stitching with just needle and thread. This jacket has been evolving for years now—first it was white, secondhand linen; then I dyed it with fermented indigo; then I pieced the scraps of blue striped cotton into a half moon; then I stitched the moon to the jacket. It had a life before me, I hope it has a life after me too.

Hi! How has it been 2+ months since I posted here? No idea. But I’ve been planning magic behind-the-scene and I’m delighted to share that Christi Johnson will be my collaborator for a second fiber arts retreat in my barn studio this fall. Hooray! The weekend of Sept 29- Oct 1 @christijay will travel across the Hudson River to co-teach, Mystical Making: Embroidery and Plant Dyes. We can’t wait to make things with you! 🔹 This workshop is meant to delight the senses and center handwork as it combines utilitarian repairs with mystical embellishments—viewing embroidery, stitching, and natural dyes as inspiration for redesign and infusing textiles with deeper value. Christi and I will share our processes in plant dyeing, stitching, and embroidery while embracing a meaningful relationship with plant-based color, slow stitching, and thoughtful design. This promises to be a special weekend for fiber arts lovers. 🔹 The workshop includes dyeing and embroidery instruction; various beautiful textile materials; shared tools; individual feedback; thoughtful vegetarian lunches, snacks and tea; and an intimate rural setting to connect with other creatives in the heart of the Hudson Valley’s beautiful landscape. Registration just opened *today*, Thursday, July 27. Details on my site. (All artwork in photos by @christijay .) I’m so excited to collaborate with you, Christi! ⭐️

The power of creativity in community is infinite! Even when those communities are just formed for a weekend. My, oh, my. The joy. The laughter. The resonance. And, of course, the artmaking. We made quilt blocks and plant dyes in my studio but we made so much more meaning than I can process yet. So good. So deep.
🔹
This past weekend’s fiber art workshops with @farmandfolk was the first time I’ve hosted a collaborative art retreat since before the pandemic. A lifetime ago. It was four years ago that I last organized bringing another artist, from far away, to collaborate in my home studio and teach with me. This weekend was everything I remember and so much more!
🔹
My heart swells that folks leapt into this unknown with me and Sara and with each other. And that they poured their hearts into their creativity and let us lead them, feed them, and make new work with them. My word. What joy. And now I have several new plant dye projects in-progress too. It’s impossible to summarize our time together but I’m reminded of what I tell my students, just keep making things. 💙 PS—Photos of student quilts, our studios, foraging, plant dyes on wool yarn, and more glimpses of the weekend.

This month marks ten years since I started Make Thrift Mend. Ten years! It’s hard to imagine that my impulse for a year-long fashion fast changed my life. And my work. Or that mending, plant-dyeing, and redesigning has dominated a decade of my life. Or that writing and teaching about it, and sometimes making tiny batches of objects or kits, has become my full-time work. Gosh!
🔹
Good glory, thank you. For being here. For sharing this space. For lighting my way. And, thank you, to that younger version of me in a tiny one-bedroom apartment in Oakland, CA ten years ago with a twenty-two-month-old baby and a budding craft business who dared to declare her one-year fast to the Internets.
🔹
If you ever bought, borrowed, or read one of my books. Sold my books. Published my articles. Took my classes. Hosted my classes. Bought my mending kits or redesigned accessories. Joined my newsletter or membership. Or even just commented and encouraged me here on IG—thank you for being part of my journey. Cheers to another decade, whatever it may bring. Let’s mend things!

PLANT DYE DREAMING.
🔹
Gosh, I love these colors! Foraging for local wildflowers, growing dye plants in my garden, and preserving food scraps for dyes all tether me to this planet and to this particular place. Collecting goldenrod from the field, clipping marigolds from my garden, or even saving avocado pits from our compost bin adds a deep connection to plants that I love to layer into my textile work.
🔹
I mostly just dye a few garments at a time. It’s slow. It’s experimental. And because my dyed clothes have several lives—light colored, to bright dye colors, to dark overdyes—I don’t need to be precise. A pot of Queen Anne’s Lace here, a bucket of Black Walnut Hulls there, or some Rudbeckia from the garden. There’s no right way. But preserving summer hues for winter months sure does *feel* right, come January. And beyond.
🔹
Some photos of recent dyes on various plant (mostly cotton, linen) and animal (mostly silk, wool) fibers from various experiments. Plants include local Queen Anne’s Lace (bright yellow); local Goldenrod (dark yellow); dried Coreopsis (orange); and definitely-not-local Avocado pits from my kitchen (pinks). I absolutely love this fiber-plant work. 🌿

I’ve mended these beloved jeans twenty-five times. They are more like a patchwork quilt than a garment. More like a series of journal entries than a pair of jeans. More love song, perhaps, than anything. My stitches record the past ten years of mending, darning and repairing my clothes. Which is simultaneously practical, and yet, passionate.
🔹
There are stories in these mended jeans. The first gash in the knee on the sidewalk near our old apartment in Oakland, CA while my young son doodled with chalk and I knelt with all the tenderness and excitement and exhaustion of a new mom. My first mending workshops are narrated through these jeans, my nerves and self-doubt remedied by kindness from bighearted students.
🔹
My progress is visible on these jeans. My techniques evolved on these jeans. I experimented and failed and improved on these jeans. And I celebrated, wept, and dreamed bigger in these jeans. I nursed babies in these jeans. I tended chickens and dye plants in these jeans. I lived through the pandemic in these jeans. As stitches patched the decade journey to denim—a practice, a commitment, an embrace of imperfection over and over again.

Inspiration is everywhere—oceanside lessons in line, color, shape and form.
🔹
We’re on Cape Cod for a week and the change in environment inspires me to pause and reconsider place and space. At every turn I see nature’s lines, colors, and shapes anew. I notice light and contrast and marvel at the hues of ocean creatures. We’re chasing the last of summer here, trying to catch August by its tail before it’s gone. When we return home my boys start third and seventh grades. Unbelievable. Yet this exclamation mark at summer’s end.
🔹
A few favorite moments here: Mended jeans and plant-dyed shawl on cedar shakes; *eleven humpback whales* so close to the boat in perfect choreography as they formed a “bubble net”; collecting rainbows of rock hues; blue water meets blue sky in one endless line; a giant moon snail shell coiled in my son’s tiny hand; cloud gazing; beach roses; lessons in the range of beautiful blues. PS—Slide 3 for whale watching magic. 🐋

I finished knitting *my first sweater*! And that’s the best thing I can tell you about this week. I’m counting this one creative win and sharing it here even though I didn’t brush my hair or style a proper photo shoot. Perhaps that chance will come when my kids are back to school. Perhaps not. Either way, I’m loving this new sweet knit. And, hello September, I made this sweater so now I’m ready for you. Pattern is Nanaimo by @good_night_day

I love mending linen. It’s a stitched ode to summer. Yet linen needs to be repaired differently from denim, silk, or wool. Each garment requires a unique mend—thank goodness. This delicate linen slip deserved an equally-delicate repair. I wanted it to maintain its drape and simplicity. Yet add texture and warmth.
🔹
I used a pink, plant-dyed linen patch, similar weight to the slip, with tucked edges. Then I chose white cotton thread for strength and it’s similarity to linen, and added pink silk thread for a hint of color—mostly just to reinforce around the torn edges and add some vertical stitches.
🔹
I love how the repair doesn’t demand too much attention as a lightweight under layer. Yet it hints at a long life, well-loved, under breezy summer dresses. It’s now back in rotation under summer dresses in this September heatwave. Though, Autumn, I know you’re out there somewhere, with sweaters.

I blinked and it’s autumn. But I’m still savoring these very last moments of fleeting summer before tomorrow’s official equinox. One last toast to my dear garden and these beloved dahlias and all the late summer sunsets that matched my every mood. It’s still warm enough for linen dresses but cool enough for wool sweaters and the moon has just been a perfect curl among stars. Hallelujah. And welcome autumn, we love you so.

Something about my first hand knit sweater over a secondhand dress dyed with black walnut hulls and donning red lipstick for a date just for one. The impractical attire for harvesting Hopi Black Dye Sunflower seeds. And how carving out time for any of it is my form of luxury as a mom running a small business. Something about waiting for the sunshine after days of rain. About slow textiles and dyes and overgrown autumn gardens. Small rebellions in a world come undone. 🌻

A love letter to goldenrod for all its glory. From the fields where it sways like earthbound sunshine to my dye pots where it keeps me tethered to slow design work, ongoing experiments like my first ever plant-dyed stripes, and preserving this color on linen pillow cases, cotton tea towels, and skeins of wool for winter. Goldenrod, you miraculous rainbow. I love you so much I painted my mudroom after you. Goldenrod, forever. 💛

I have *big mending news*. I’m teaching a new 5-week online mending course this winter. I’ve been dreaming about it since I published Mending Matters in 2018–recorded videos with an intimate look at my techniques, design, tools, materials, and more. For five years I’ve imagined these writings, photos, videos, live studio sessions, and online community. But how?
🔹
Fast forward to 2022 when I was contacted by a big teaching platform to make a class. But after months of negotiations, I walked away. Heartbroken. Then I got curious—could I produce it myself? And in August 2022 I hired a videographer and editor to shoot the classes in my barn. And we did it! By ourselves. And now I can finally share it with you. I’m opening this course for registration TOMORROW.
🔹
It will run from Jan 22- Feb 23, 2024. Five weeks of edited videos, weekly live sessions (also recorded), new writing, photos, artist features, creative prompts, and an online community to brighten the winter months. Some things take time. So much time. But I’m delighted to offer this course. Finally. Let’s mend things together. Video by @karenpearsonphoto

I’m SO delighted to offer a new visible mending course this winter. ON THE MEND runs online from January 22- February 23, 2024. Professionally-recorded and edited videos share full tutorials on mending and darning; insights into my favorite tools and materials; an entire chapter on how I use design elements like line, color, and shape; and a bonus chapter with a peak at Swiss Darning.
🔹
 It’s a five-week, online mending course with instructor feedback. Recorded videos, released weekly, share full tutorials on mending and darning. Written lessons offer creative prompts and featured artists, to deepen your experience. A private community classroom is included for feedback and inspiration. And… I’ll host live, 45-minute studio sessions, and offer them recorded afterwards.
🔹
Newsletter subscribers get a special Earlybird offer that expires *tomorrow, Monday, November 27, at 11:59pm EST*. If you’re already on my list—awesome and thank you, it’s my favorite spot to connect. If you’re not, hop over there ASAP to get one last offer in tomorrow’s letter. Let’s mend things. Together.

You’ve asked some great questions so I’m sharing more insights about my new visible mending course, ON THE MEND. It’s live with me online from January 22- February 23, 2024. And it’s based on professionally-recorded and edited videos too. It’s both synchronous and asynchronous. Together.
🔹
 It’s a five-week, online mending course with instructor feedback on your mending projects. Recorded videos, written lessons, and a private interactive community classroom to engage at your own pace. And… I’ll host live, 45-minute studio sessions, and offer them recorded afterwards.
🔹
Today’s the last day newsletter subscribers get a special Earlybird offer that expires on *Monday, November 27, at 11:59pm EST*. If you’re already on my list—awesome and thank you. If you’re not, hop over there now to get one last offer in today’s letter, sending soon.
